SLA definitions

SLA definitions are used to define a specific set of criteria for an SLA. You must define some of the following parameters:

  • Type: Associate a specific service level target with the SLA/OLA/Underpinning contract to sort or search for service level agreements by type.
    Note: Type is used for reporting purposes only.
  • Table: Specify the task table against which you define the SLA.
  • Workflow: Select the workflow to be associated with the SLA to control notification and escalation procedures.
  • Duration type: Specify the method for calculating the duration which can be a user specific duration or a duration relative to a point in time or due date from a related task.
  • Duration: Specify the time duration by which you must provide the specific service to the customer.
  • Schedule source: Specify the schedule source that defines the valid working and non-working days that the service provider follows to deliver the service. The selected schedule is used to determine SLA breach.
  • Schedule: Specify the business calendar that controls SLA business time duration accumulation.
  • Timezone source/Timezone: Specify the source and the timezone an SLA uses that impacts the in-and-out of schedule duration accumulation.
  • Conditions: Specify the conditions under which the SLA must start, pause, stop, or reset.
